I was in the Navy, but my stint was between any real conflicts, so I never really did anything other than just the job of keeping the machine running. Jet boats are very cool, but for me they're mostly connected to bad memories. In Sweden our Combat Boat 90s are small boats made to transport infantry around small islands in our archipelagos. They approach the landing site at very high speed, then reverse the thrust to brake very fast. Sadly, sometimes they don't hit the brake early enough, and slam into the beach or pier. This has led to the CB90 being by far the vehicle in our inventory that's killed the most soldiers.

I lived on the Washington coast for awhile and the weather gets nasty at times. Out of Westport (which is on the 'Graveyard of the Pacific', but not as rough as the mouth of the Columbia, by Neah Bay), in the winter time, it is common to lose a ship or boat to rough seas....usually fishing or crabbing vessels.

So, on rough weather days, I knew the boats werent going out..... but on the way to work at the harbor, the Coast Guard folks would be ecstatic about the horrible weather. Bad Weather Training! They LOVED that stuff! You'd see them, later, jumping from helicopters or crossing the bar in a small craft...and they lived for this stuff!

...used to make me jealous, but, at the same time, brought me back to reality: i couldnt have done that ever in my life. i was never fit enough. They are doing things i couldnt have ever accomplished and enjoying it!

I have a ton of respect for them!

Years ago on Bogue sound in North Carolina,  A sailboat from the local sailing school got in trouble.  I was nearby in my powerboat.  I rendered what assistance I could, made sure everyone was safe and left the scene because there was nothing more that I could do (they had a catamaran with a flooded hull on one side).  The water was less than 4ft.  As I was leaving the scene, The Coast Guard came rushing to save the day!  They had an outboard  and larger boat than mine, but they lacked the local knowledge of the area.  As I was exiting in the only channel to the cat, they were trying to Bull their way through a shallower cut and were aground.  I kept waving to them to come to where I was, but they would not listen.  I don't know if they ever got through, probably not because it was very shallow for a boat their size.  I was active duty Navy at the time.

Hamilton Marine designed the jet units in the 1950s in New Zealand. I went to their workshop in 1963 as an apprentice Motor Mechanic, they were building jet boats with V8 Motors to go up the rivers in NZ I have been on these boats they handle very well they stop on a dime a lot of fun in the rivers. I am not saying the jet units on these boats are hamilton jets

First of all, I have nothing but respect for what the host does for this channel, I am subscribed and an avid watcher. But I have to call him out on saying it requires a computer to walk a boat sidewise.

I'm a 20-year retired navy veteran, And among many other things I was tasked with in my career, Was in the 1980s, I worked at an oil recovery unit at 32st Naval Station in San Diego for three years. I am very proud that I was able to accomplish certification as a coxswains mate (which wasn't even part of my rating, I was a machinist mate) And after certification I was given my own work boat and crew. We (The unit) were tasked with cleaning up oil spills in the bay, AND, we recovered over a million gallons of spilled oil in the bay, each and every year !!

We had many different types of boats, The most important being the skimmer boat that removed the oil from the surface of the water. But our main work horse was a 40-foot utility boat, what most people would identify, (via the movies) as the boat used to land troops on the beach in a land invasion, (minus the front drop gate).

A big diesel powered air compressor was up on the deck on the bow above the cargo area, which was filled up with large, air powered diaphragm pumps and waste oil tanks. Anyway, for propulsion it had two diesel engines and a simple steering wheel, my point is, that by turning the wheel in the correct direction, and directing one engine forward and one engine in reverse we were able to "walk" the boat sidewise, all without the use of a computer. it was all about the ability of the coxswain, it didn't require a computer.

Over and above that, I'm not trying to cast any aspersions on the people involved with this channel. I think this website is by and far an outstanding example of what social media should be and I applaud everything they do. Keep up the good work guys, and girls, (if there are any.) You have my gratitude for all that you do.

Just finished watching the last episode of the new Star Trek (SNW). I made the unfortunate mistake of watching many of your videos over the last few years. Knowing how professional all the fine people serving on submarines, helicopters, boats and such makes any crew of a Starship look like a bunch of lucky beautiful people galavnting through the universe, chancig their luck and going more or less blindly into their adventures. Despite the fact that their supposed to be the top tier, the finest people serving on star ships.
It's actually an insult to all the fine folks like everyone in the video above. Running casualties, checking all the systems, being completely an utterly an example of people that are in the right place.
Destin's videos are one of the few rare places showing the amount of devotion and proffesional pride these people take in doing their best.
Then you watch a show like Star Trek or any non sci-fi show depicting teams of people working in unison and it seems like no one trains for anything, there are no guidelines, no best procedures, it's all about the captains emotional integrity, courage and gut feeling. I get it's entertainment, but I completely get why Destin is geeking out on cameras in the engine bay and hydraulics and all the fine stuff. Life is more interesting and makes lazy written TV shows look so stupid.... Thanks for yet another cool video!

Bit of jetboat history; bill Hamilton from New Zealand invented the modern water jet as we know it today. He grew up just down the road from my family farm and his original workshop is still there. He did an interesting publicity stunt with Edmund Hillary where they took a couple jet boats up the Ganges river from the mouth to the top most headwaters in the Himalayas. Hamilton jets I believe are what the US coastguard use - albeit as a license built copy.

Pull the dipstick out clean it off. Reinsert it all the way in. Take it out again and then check the level. Best way to get an accurate oil level. If the engine was just turned off, wait for the oil to resettle in the oil pan. Then check it. If the engine been off for a long time. I would still use the clean, reinsert and then check. Most accurate reading that way.

jet propulsion is less efficient than propellers. This is due to er .. physics. Same thrust is produced moving a lot of water slowly (propeller) as moving less water at high speed (jet), but the power needed for jet is much more. This is obvious just looking at the turbulent energy lost in the wake. Using jet propulsion in open water, where propellers are not at risk bumping into anything is just dumb.

BTW Your boat crew for the demo was an E-4 (MK3) and an E-3 (Non-Rate yet) Seaman.

These boats are made to withstand rolling over and the Coxsains are trained at a USCG boat station on the Columbia River = (Big, Mean Water). Much respect. These boats are a big upgrade from the old 41' that were just plain boring and gutless. We lost a USCG 41' there on the jetties near Station Destin years ago with coastie casualties.

Dude, you were in my "backyard" filming this segment on the Gulf Coast, I retired to Gulf Shores, AL after 21 years of service but I flew out of ATC Mobile my last SEVEN years of my military career while living in the house I grew up in over in Pensacola, loved it. Upon first entering the Guard I was stationed at "Group" Mobile as a Non-Rate, used the Travel Lift to lift boats up out of the water for maintenance/inspection, and went over to the Aviation side of the house for a much different career path = home at night. Our boat side guys work hard for a living and we supported them in many ways. We were the "Bird Dogs" while they were hands-on with the customer in many cases.

21 years in I worked on different airframes but was only qualified on the HC-130, HU-25, and H-60. DropMaster/LoadMaster/Flight Mech.


Funny note, I worked in the marine division in the offshore oilfield prior to the USCG and just wanted to look at the world from a little higher point of view. Not better, but just a change in scenery.

From a former Coastie: If you want some serious click-worthy video, get yourself some time on a Polar class Ice Breaker. The USCGC Polar Star (WAGB-10) was "recently" recomissioned, and is one of the most storied vessles in the Coast Guard. Ask about the effort to rescue/recover the Arctic Rose! Aside from high profile stories like the loss of the Arctic Rose, Polar Class Ice Breakers are AMAZING in their own right. Controllable pitch propellers, canted frames (to withstand breaking Ice sheets), MASSIVE diesel engines (that often overheated or developed fractures), and even steam leaks that required mid-ocean repair with humans working in 170deg+ environments; all-the-while working to help facilitate a better understanding of our Earth in it's most extreme climes, make the Polar Class Ice Breaker an amazing frame in which you can help people get "Smarter Every Day"! A few years ago I went to Petaluma to help train Army National Guard Engineers. Petaluma is where all coast guard chefs are trained. They are not taught how to be cooks, they are taught how to be chefs! And Friday's at the culinary school are phenomenal! Everything the chefs-in-training have learned to prepare and cook every week is served up as an entire Captain's buffet. And the line to get in and partake of this feast gets loooong! Everyone wants a taste of the thick cuts of prime rib the size of the entire plate, many kinds of specially prepared crab and fish and other proteins, soups, veggies, casseroles, pastas, desserts.... and it's AYCE. Destin... it would be awesome if you went to the USCG Training Center in Petaluma, CA to bring us an episode on the Coast Guard Culinary School! 👨‍🍳👩‍🍳😋

If you ever get a chance to visit Southeast Alaska, look up Allen Marine Tours. They build and operate a fleet of dual hulled jet boats out of Sitka and Juneau. Some of their ferry boats found a home in New York and rescued passengers off Captain Sullenberger's plane. Anyway, a great company and fantastic boats in a beautiful place. We used boats very similar to these while I was in the navy. We had  a variety of boats that all ran off of the jets. We had a patrol boat used for harbor defense that was 34 feet and we had a RPB or riverine patrol boat and the RAB ( riverine assault boat). The biggest difference between this boat and ours was all of the controls are manual inputs. The throttle and bucket inputs were manipulated by levers at the coxswain station, so you had to have a great feel for the boat and how it handles in order to do everything. The crew was also young just like this I was a coxswain at 20.

I am impressed at so many levels...

I have been a volunteer firefighter for 15 years. I became a candidate at the age of 18, and I respectfully retired from this service at the age of 33 as an engineer.

I recognize the youthful enthousiasm from this team. They are as enthusiastic as a young puppy. But when it becomes serious, they can show the discipline from a sheepdog, or the fighting spirit from a pitbull.

Par exemple: When dustin asks Justin at 10:21 : "Is he getting the boat ready for you"?,
Justin replies, "for the CREW, yeah". 
CREW. Plurar....
They have been trained to work as a TEAM. And therefore, they can rely on each other, no matter what happens...

Off course i've seen footage of the US coast guard bootcamp, and I know is no joke. This is where the change from a child to an adult begins. But thanks to this training program, they are prepared do to a job when they have to do it.

Furthermore; I haven't passed my exam for a driver's license until I became 25 years old, but this team 'pilots' a boat at the age of 20. But it doesn't end there. They are the first aiders that comes to a scene. They MUST provide help for the needy, or show aggression towards the people who wants to do harm...

I have nothing but respect for this team, or any other 'coastie' on service!

Do what you love, and love what you do.

Thank you @SmarterEveryDay for sharing this footage!

P.S., hearing that diesel baby start at 9:16, made my hart skip a beat!

As someone who owns a 550 hp 21 foot jetboat, I think they are awesome. Infinite forward/reverse proportion, quick acceleration, quick deceleration, very few moving parts, very robust, and borderline impossible to get hurt/cut by the drive.

Some of the disadvantages is very little or no steering when at idle and a boat with a jet drive is typically slower top speed than a similar size/power boat that uses a prop.

A brilliant Kiwi invention! Jet boats were originally designed by Bill Hamilton in New Zealand to "fly" up shallow South Island rivers where the gravel banks would destroy propellers. They'd just fly over a gravel bank, continue at high speed in inches of water, so fast and manoeuvrable. An awesome tourism "adventure experience", a little frightening but great adrenaline rush!

What a superb video! Reminds me of great times on larger yachts. Destin would love to explore using “beating”, a mathematical waveform phenomenon, using acoustics to synchronize two engines.  (Lookup beating wave.) Synchronizing is important for maximizing efficiency, especially on longer journeys. Once you understand it, it’s very easy to do. The RB-M drive is similar to the Volvo Penta IPS, which uses multiple, counterrotating screws, that can be aimed independently, unlike the RB-M. The IPS allows for some amazing tricks, too. Imagine going down into the engine room with extremely hot and noisy engines spinning inches from you in a rough sea - now that’s fun. Bringing a good-sized boat with twin screws into a berth or leaving - and doing it gracefully - is just so cool. When the RB-M left on that emergency call, it sure didn’t minimize its wake in a harbor, but I suppose that they’re allowed to do that.

Jet drive boats have a lot of advantages over outboard -- safety when someone is in the water near the stern and reduced draft being the two main ones.  I had always owned outboard motor boats for freshwater fishing, but I bought a jet boat at one point.  There are some things that I found more inconvenient than an outboard though.  When the grating over the impeller intake gets clogged with seaweed / aquatic vegetation, you often cannot clear it without diving under the boat.  Even worse is if a rope gets sucked into the impeller intake and wrapped around the impeller shaft.  This is not as quick to fix because it has made it past the grating and you need to spend a lot more time removing the grating (with tools and hoping that you don't drop the screws / bolts in the process).  You really need a SCUBA rig to do this since it takes long enough that you will not be holding your breath to do it.  It's one thing to do this when in the calm waters tied up to a dock in a harbor, but it's quite another thing to do it when you are a few miles offshore even if the seas are only 2-3 ft... I quickly learned to HATE those polypropylene black crab pot ropes... When your wife runs over the ski rope and gets it sucked into the impeller, it's not fun either... :(

Old mate did not tell you about the special amount of angle variance that is inputted between the steering of a dual output assembly (rudders). One side of the engine output has turn more than the other when you are turning, this is achieved through the mechanical linkage between the two outputs and is why one ram for dual steering instead of the easier and cheaper dual rams. This is the only reason the sideways mauvers work as well, some crazy marine engineering maths.  The funny thing is it seems your graphics guy knows about this funny mechanic trait, as it looked like they displayed this need/trait in the graphics and even got the additional turn side correct :)

In Australia, insurance companies stopped insuring boats with jets years ago. Just too many of them kept slamming into other things. The problem is that when they are in the water they get growth on the bucket control arms, and when you're coming into a mooring pen, and you select reverse and the bucket doesn't drop because of the growth, you keep going forward. And as most people give the throttle a squirt after selecting reverse, that just means you hit the thing in front of you even harder. Also, having driven jet boats and sterndrive boats, jets DO NOT respond well at low speed. I suspect the RBMs have bow thrusters to help. Don't need those with a sterndrive.

Yep - as Kiwis we are very proud of Bill Hamilton, who invented the jetboat and jet unit. It was invented to access river locations where other methods were not possible. And today, jetboats can get to the places even helicopters can't! Today, NZ continues to pioneer with tiny single-person jetboats able to run in about 2cm of water.

We are also pretty proud of Richard Pearce who was the first man to fly, some time before the Wright brothers, and in a much more sophisticated aircraft, complete with ailerons, which he patented, and never made a cent from. But history was unkind to Pearce, as his definition of "flight" was being able to fly a pattern, navigate, and land. A reproduction of his plane (Parts recovered from a Temuka dump) can be seen at the MOTAT museum in Auckland.

How old is this boat? I wrote a story about eight years ago about building one. It was designed as a pursuit to catch go fast boats from international waters to shore or river bank. Interestingly it had all the features of this one although I had different terms for the components. I used v12 on road diesels as they were lighter. The boat was 35 feet long and 8 feet wide. To get the performance for river operations it had a flat bottom the rear third with twin vertical fins on both sides for stability and to steer against. This not a new design. They used jet boats in Vietnam. They were only about 20 feet long but had a lot of weapons on them. Since I had zero experience with boats I had to use my imagination. It's interesting how close my idea is to reality. The history of the Coast Guard is good reading. They wear a ton of hats.

As usual, the video was very well done and very interesting. Coincidentally, the drive system on the Coast Guard's Jet Boat is very similar to the drive system on my own Jet Boat. The big difference is sophistication and cost. I have an 18 foot SeaDoo Sportster with dual engines and dual jet pumps. It also uses the "buckets" for reversing. The two jet pump steering nozzles are linked mechanically to ensure they are parallel.

I learned how to make the bow plow into the water by going fast and slamming the buckets into reverse and then go full throttle. The back will rise and cause the nose to dive. An actual wave of solid water will roll into the boat. My passengers get a big kick out of that. They also get very wet!

The Coast Guard is a great service. I have a unique perspective to compare the Coast Guard to United States Navy. I was a machinist mate (MM1) in the engine room on a nuclear powered fast attack submarine and then machinery technician (MK1) on the Great Lakes as an reservist.
Both were very professionally fulfilling. I have heard people say uncomplimentary things about the Coast Guard and that it is not a real military unit and give it less respect than the other branches of service. What I found was professionalism that equals that of the US submarine force and a knowledge per person that has to be wider in breath due to the limited number of rates (professions) in the Coast Guard.

I am just as proud to say that I was in the USCG Reserve as I am to say that I was in the USN.

Interesting Coast Guard facts:

Despite the US having a military budget larger than any other 5 nations combined, in 2021 the coast Guard said they "cannot continue to fulfill its responsibilities effectively" without an additional $3B in funding.

The Coast Guard has had a few white supremacist problems. in 2018 an officer was reprimanded for flashing a white power hand gesture while in the background of a news shot, and in 2021, a lieutennant was jailed for stockpiling weapons and planning a white supremacist terrorist attack.

The Coast Guard has a significant problem with diversity, one that gets worse the farther up the command structure you go. Despite that, Women and Black personnel have lower retention rates than their majority counterparts, leaving fewer of them available to serve.

That's particularly troubling since in the years after 9/11 almost half of military enlistees said they experienced traumatic events during their time in the military, making it harder to attract new recruits.

You gotta remember...we treat water just the same as air. We consider air "fluid" even though it's not in a liquid state however it flows just like a liquid would. That's why we can use the same concept of trim, elevator(interceptors on this boat), the buckets on jet flow(think of reverse thrust in jet engines...same concept by using something to just redirect the thrust). Think space shuttles, come in too shallow of an angle and it can literally skip across the atmosphere(just like skipping a rock on water). There are some differences but they basically work the same.

Those Jet Drives are great in the 25-50 mph range for fuel consumption.. best at higher ranges. Were it not for keeping bubbles of air out of the drive being difficult at 50+ miles Per hour the efficiency would remain to much higher speeds. I've tried to design a number of hulls that had 'Tunnels' but can't come up with one that has smooth solid intake with Catamaran or Trimaran designs that are needed for really high speeds on larger boats like 80+ feet and 80+ mph.

Well no they are not so awesome, a simple prop is far more efficient than sa jet pump, with a given engine you will go faster with a prop, be more fuel-efficient, and have far fewer breakdowns and maintenance with a prop system. They are touted as a low water craft but the jet intake will suck up debris from the bottom and bring the pump to a screeching halt, For shallow water, you are far better off with a surface drive. It's a poor choice and an inferior propulsion system all around.

As I said in your previous video on the search and rescue missions I am a fan of analog systems.
Again, I love that there are still analog testers for such things as oil viscosity. Not because I am against electronics, or such (heck, I worked in IT most of my life).

But a) because the simplicity yet ingenuity of many of these testers fascinates me, and b) because they will work ALL the time, won't need constant calibration, energy, can't be disrupted by a storm, affected by a solar flare, or a hundred other such factors. Simple gravity and resistance due to surface area and passing volumes through a pre-gauged gap. That's it. Once it's calibrated mechanically it is fairly difficult to decalibrate. They fall in the water or sand, get dirty, you name it. No worries, clean and dry them out, and they are probably ready to go immediately. Electronics on the other hand do tend to collect condensed water over time, and in a maritime environment that chance increases a LOT. So in essence analog systems have nearly the same reasons to fail as electronic systems but can be easily restored to working order in most cases with very simple tools. Electronics, once broken, usually require replacement.

While electronics will often give results a bit quicker than analog systems, the time gains most often are only marginal, as some physical aspect has to be tested which simply requires a certain time to pass. So a time gain through electronics often is superficial, and the sturdiness of a device is of a higher value than the speed gain.

I wish I still ran a supply boat in the Gulf, I'd invite you for a run out into the oil fields and show you what an experienced helmsman can do with a 150 foot boat. The jet drive is indeed fast and cool, and the boat can definitely stop and reverse faster than a conventionally driven boat, BUT the handling of the boat is exactly the same on a boat with two fixed wheels (propellers) and two rudders, each aligned directly in the wheel wash. The ability to move your boat sideways through the water is called "crabbing" or "crab walking" and every captain and/or wheelman running a supply boat out to the Gulf oil platforms NEEDS to develop this skill quickly.; The primary function of a supply boat is to deliver fuel, water, personnel, materials and expendables to the oil platforms. In almost every case the platform has a crane on a deck some 100 to 150 feet above the water and the boat MUST remain fixed in the water under that crane regardless of sea conditions, current and wind direction. The off load and reload of waste products to and from the platform can take several hours to half a day to even longer and it is forbidden to tie the supply boat up to the platform's legs or to drop anchor. This play of opposing, variable thrust and using the rudders to direct the forward thrusting wheel wash to one side or another, much like a stern thruster, is a dance I did with my boat almost every day for quite a number of years. I actually learned to "crab walk" on a 235 foot passenger vessel (a casino boat in the Carolinas), and learned to do it without using the bow thruster. I've also used the same technique on a tug boat pushing three 120 foot barges secured end to end.
I'm not bragging about this, I'm pointing out that this handling ability is not unique to a jet drive boat.

I'm kind of surprised that Destin was surprised over the engine system on that boat. A lot of medium size boats, 40'-70' range are either using IPS or Zeus drive systems. The IPS system gives you two forward-facing props, in pods, and each is independently steerable and can control the throttle and direction. In fact, with either system, you can turn a 60' yacht on a dime, and literally, turn the boat 360º in its own length. You can also drive it sideways, and it's all done with a small joystick at the helm (or any place else on the boat you want to install it).

I would think that on the RBM the steering would be separate, one for each pump jet, but I also see why it may not be necessary in this regard.

I think Justin managed to understate just how big a thing it is to just do those training exercises. Like they pull out the book to show him one and someone else instantly pipes up with a "Let's run it." That level of continual practice is what makes organizations like the USCG able to get full use of all their equipment and then some. As they note, having this level of practice as part of their routine means that it's "muscle memory" when it happens for real. Real occurrences are almost normal because they practice so much they probably sometimes forget a real occurrence is not a training exercise.

Note that this isn't some special US or even USCG thing. All organizations known for their professionalism are like this around the world. It's an organizational culture thing, not national culture.

I used to skipper an old jet-drive passenger boat on the River Thames. Nowhere near as fancy as this beast, she had only a single engine, with one nozzle and bucket. But even just with that setup, you could maneuver in some remarkable ways once you got used to it. No fancy computer controls, just careful balancing of the throttle, helm and bucket, and you could almost go sideways. I never got to go fast, but I got great satisfaction from the look on canal-boater's faces when I would spin that 60ft plastic bathtub on the spot: "You have bow thrusters on that thing?" Nah, I'm just really good ;-)

Watching this, it hit me: I get to do this for a living. I'm a technical writer; my job is to write user manuals. Companies contract us to write the user manuals for their products. My father was first to use three stage units each driven by a 7 litre V8, alloy intercepter four Holly carbs, hot cams, with some eight hundred horsepower. A work boat to save helicopter time extracting high mountain deer. It could slide over wet rocks at fifty mph. When it got back into water we call it  knots. Best work boat with twelve skiers behind.

I never cease to be amazed and impressed by how methodical US defense systems work.

Some things are very simple: A half-hour process whereby the people charged with maintaining Coast Guard vessels make sure they are ready to go to work. Some relatively simple checks on the oil quality mean that a) the engines will have the maximum reasonable lifetime and b) they are in good working condition and c) aren't likely to fail at a critical time. A ten minute process to ensure the electrical systems are operative and ready to work.

Some things less obvious: Having young, trained, and motivated people doing this work. A career path open to people from all backgrounds. You won't see commissioned Officers of any US service holding tools. Because they don't need to. Because they''ve got NCOs and enlisted people who are trained, trusted, and (more-than) capable of keeping the moving parts clean and working.

I cannot help but compare the image of young Americans competently (dare I say joyously?) getting their Coast Guard Jet Boat ready for a day of rescuing day sailors with the sad picture of Russian tanks and APCs busted down and abandoned in Ukraine for want of tires that aren't dry-rotted or fuel systems that aren't hopelessly contaminated. Because they don't pay the conscripts to do the work, and horribly haze and abuse those that do manage to show up for work not drunk.
These young people are quite literally amazing and sooo inspirational. 💪

Hey Destin - there's a moment in there that's one of my pet peeves, but is also a really interesting subject that you might be a good person to explore - either as a video or as a regular sidelight. One of the Coasties shows their dropping ball viscosity test for used motor oil (which is awesome). But he calls it "very analog." Everyone knows what he means, and this is the term a lot of us would come up with for what he means. But it's not analog at all. It's *actual*. Analog is a readout that somehow reflects reality directly (that is an analog, an analogy of reality) without being mediated by a digital computer or any quantized stage. A dial indicator on a fuel gauge, for example. But with a device like this, there is not even that distance from the thing being measured. This is a direct measurement in a way an analog electric fuel gauge is not. This would make a great subject for further study: cool direct measurement gauges and tools. Especially for things like viscosity where the way to get such direct measurements is not necessarily obvious.

Actually, with the vector stick system they seem to be using there is almost zero interpretation from a computer. The stick position translates directly to bucket, rev and nozzle positions, meaning it's up to us to actually adjust the inputs for rhe desired result.

There are systems that use a single stick where you can just thrist sideways or whatever, which does heavily rely on a hydrodynamics model, but that's not what they're using.

For reference, I drive the equivalent kind of SAR jetboats in the Norwegian civilian counterpart to the coastguard (we just do search and rescue and maritime assistance. The martial coasties do the judicial stuff). We gave jetboats that use both the same system as the RBM as well as a different rolls royce system.

But the sticks just tell the buckets and nozzles where to go. It's up to us to understand where we need them in order to make the boat do what we need it to do.

Which is imho more impressive and cooler than having a computer do it ;)

Having grown up around jet boats, and living in city where Hamilton Jet is based (the inventors of the modern marine jet propulsion systems in the 50's) this was very cool. If anyone wants to experience a large commercial craft going crazy speeds come whale watching in Kaikoura off the east coast of the South Island. Unfortunately many people are taken unaware of the speeds and get quite sea-sick... but it's a blast... and of course river jet boat trips is a large part of our tourism highlights too!

It is a good boat and at that speed range up to 43 knots, it must use about two to four gallons per mile. Very thirsty engines at about 2800 rpm.
The propulsion system is good, so simple, and useful for the purpose, in this case, but that propulsion system is not so efficient for long-range and one needs to pay through the nose for that convenience rather than performance and efficiency. It is fine as long as the state pays for it. At those revolutions, the engines would need good continuous supervision. The enclosed impellers are liable to cavitate and the metal erodes quite fast. There is a lot of pressure built up and the diffusers/nozzles at the back, which can act as amplifiers and accelerate the water flow after the impeller does its bit. The noise of those engines is deafening and they need soundproofing and a camera, as no human ear will ever be comfortable standing in between those engines when underway. Those crafts are like fighter aircraft and one needs to select the crew to be between twenty to twenty-five years and have a light structure and a good spine to take the pounding in higher waves but not too high, as that craft will not take it. I remember the old Air-sea WW2 rescue boats with aircraft Merlin engines and the Packard- Merlin which was made in the US and had better tolerances than the British Merlin engine.
The craft shown in this video is more maneuverable than the British boats, but the latter were better for longer-distance comforts, for the more aged crew!! Yes, I am that old!

About the closing remarks: props to the Coast Guard since they're not DoD and absolutely serving a meaningful purpose. Army/Marines/Air Force definitely have their place but CG is a cut above the rest when it comes to their mission.

The RBMs reminded me of the Navy's Pegasus-class hydrofoil boats.  As a Civilian Naval employee back them, I didn't get to ride on any, but did get to visit two while they were in a local port back in the '80s.  They were NATO-designed & built by Boeing, so at least some parts were built like aircraft.  The boats had cracking problems with the exhaust stacks (vibration caused, I think) and Boeing's lead time and cost were unacceptable to the Navy at the time.  I worked at the local Naval Air Rework Facility, and we were asked to build the replacement exhaust stacks because they were designed & built like aircraft.  If I remember correctly, they used diesel-powered water jets at low speeds and turbine engines for the water jets for higher speeds.  The Navy wouldn't admit to their upper speed capability back then, but we were told that it was impressive.  I suspect that since the ships are long decommissioned, the official performance specs are now available.  (Wikipedia says they were 133-feet [41-m] long with a 28-foot [8.5-m] beam and had speeds of 12 knots hullborne and 48 knots foilborne.)

All those "pre-flight checks" are to keep your tax dollars running and ensure they are used most efficiently.
When I was in the Army, as a mechanic, I was surprised that we didn't change engine oil on a schedule, but based upon the results of oil testing. We didn't do the testing, it was sent elsewhere, but the results would determine if the oil needed to be changed. Or in rare circumstances, when the engine needed replacement before failure.
Thank about all of that the next time you jump in your car and take off. That government owned equipment (vehicles, generators, ect.) is checked, inspected and documented at the beginning of each working day before they are used to ensure they will operate as expected. And as the case in my unit, even if they were not being actively used; they were checked, started and ran once each week.

One really cool feature you didn't mention, or maybe you did and I missed it; these boats, like the 47' MLB, are self-righting. If they get knocked down in heavy surf, as long as the boat is physically intact, it will roll upright within a few seconds to a minute. Probably less of a concern in the Gulf, but where I live in the Pacific Northwest, the surf stations deal with that kind of water as their daily commute, especially in the winter.

What I learned in this video: those boats are just like helicopters. They both have a huge checklist before "take off", they both use joysticks to steer, they're both extremely loud, and both need to have three variables constantly adjusted to move as intended. The helo's are the main rotor's angle, the back rotor's angle, and rotor speed. The boat's are the engine speed, steering, and buckets position. The only difference is that one works thanks to aerophysics and the other works thanks to nautical physics.

"They ended up saving four souls on this distress call" 1:30
This immediately caught my attention and I was compelled to search and find the release on that rescue to learn how you used the term "souls".... as it means different things in different scenarios. In some cases, "souls" is used to account for those both alive, and dead. Thankfully, it is found to be the prior. For anyone who may have also caught that, or wondered what the situation was that was referenced for that quote, see below:

From the Defense Visual Information Distribution Service (DVIDS):
CORPUS CHRISTI, TX, UNITED STATES 10.31.2013 Courtesy Story U.S. Coast Guard District 8 PADET Houston
The Coast Guard rescued four people from a sailboat caught in high seas and winds, due to severe weather in the area, approximately 24 miles offshore of Matagorda Bay, Thursday.
Sector Corpus Christi watchstanders received a distress signal from a SPOT device on the 18-foot sailboat. Watchstanders launched an MH-65 Dolphin helicopter and HU-25 Falcon jet from Corpus Christi as well as a 45-foot Response Boat — Medium from Station Port O’Connor.
The Falcon crew located the sailboat in distress and vectored in the boat crew. They took the sailboat in tow safely back to port.
The four people had no reported injuries or medical concerns.

I'm ex-US Coast Guard, 1974-79. 5 and 1/2 years of the very best time in my life. I was a Boatswain Mate, and search and rescue boat coxswain. I'm glad to see the improvements they've made to the boats. I drove a 30ftr, 40ftr 44 MLB and a 32ft Port and Waterway Safety boat. I was in 2 SAR (Search And Rescue) Stations in Michigan and Capt. of the Port New Orleans. The jobs in the Coast Guard come with all the excitement you can stand. Also you must remember, The Coast Guard is the ONLY service, that has a job in Peace Time, we were not sitting around waiting for a war to break out! (hehe) We did more with nothing, then any other organization did with all the resources in the world. And we got the job done. Proud of these guys and gals, very proud. Thanks for showcasing the USCG!!!

The turns with dissimilar thrust reminds me of helicopter's ability. A task of doing a 360 around a point can be done several ways;
1. Nose stays at the point and everything aft does the circle
2. Center of helo is over the point and a 360 done in place
3. Tail at the point, and the bulk of the helo pivots around that as a stationary point
4. Same as #1, but nose begins/stays say 20' back from the center point
* Rinse/repeat with a headwind, tailwind and crosswind for extra spicy goodness

Build fantastic skills as with so many things, repetition and you don't even think about the "how", you just do it.

Interesting, first real jet boats were use during Vietnam river patrol boats.   They were Swift Boats, based off Sewart Seacraft cruiser hull,  used dual Jacuzzi pump water jets with thrust buckets were produce and powered by Detroit Diesels.   They could go 32 knots.

I would expect that AF vs CG really depends on what your job ends up being. I did six years in the Chair Force, flying a desk doing IT. I was never responsible for much of anything beyond my personal gear and being supervisor to a few Airmen. I had a Brother in Law who was a Coastie and at the same rank he was directly responsible for a multi-million dollar boat and it's crew for 1/3 of the time. He got to do a lot more traveling as well as I did all six years at one base while he did a lot of PCS'ing. That said I ended up with six years of experience in a career field that has been very good for earning a living since I separated. It really comes down to what you want to be doing and what they'll let you sign up for.

Destin, you may want to watch the video with Closed Captioning turned on. There were some rather interesting mistranslations. For starters, the software confused the currency British Pound with the Imperial Weight Pound when talking about pulling a 250 pound individual out of the water. It's mistranslated parts of the ship, crew names, and even displayed "Ow, ow, ow..." when the ship's siren was turned on at the end of the video.

I use the closed captioning because there are often parts where environmental noise (both on your videos and on my end) tends to be louder than the speech in the video making it hard to make out what's being said. (Plus, I have Tinnitus from a long list of things, including many years of marching band.) I'm able to catch a lot of these mistakes, but someone with either more severe or complete hearing loss will be at the mercy of the translation software. I know this is more work on your end, but can you add your script (and interview dialog) to the videos so those with hearing impairments can follow along?

When dealing with performance engines at the limit, don't skimp on a half quart of motor oil. I learned this the hard way when taking my car out to Laguna Seca. Being right in the middle of my oil level marker of the dipstick, meant I was half a quart below FULL. I was thinking well within the range I should be fine. Right up until I'm taking a high G turn, and when I come out I get a tremendous bearing knock and need a new motor. Bummer.

I actually fix those 45s day in and out, good boats, and im going to give u a tip… the propulsion system is Rolls Royce. I bet u didn’t know that.

2nd tip, the impellers are always rotating in the direction of forward even when you go in reverse…. So… when you go in neutral is not actually neutral, it’s actually a perfect “reverse bucket engagement “ in a 50% forward and 50% reverse, therefore canceling each other resulting in the boat not moving in an apparent “neutral “

I appreciate you and your work. As a Coastie who served in SAR, I also did a tour in Attu, Alaska. That island is repleat with an interesting history. The Japanese fought there in WW2, before it was U.S. soul. We had the only C-130 to crash was on that island in the 80's, and we could hike to the wreckage in the early 2000s.
